application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

keywords.term: Swarm and Evolutionary Computation BASE DATA artificial bee colony

div.p: In portfolio optimization (PO), often, a risk measure is an objective to be minimized or an efficient frontier representing the best tradeoff between return and risk is sought. In order to overcome computational difficulties of this NP-hard problem, a growing number of researchers have adopted swarm intelligence (SI) methodologies to deal with PO. The main PO models are summarized, and the suggested SI methodologies are analyzed in depth by conducting a survey from the recent published literature. Hence, this study provides a review of the SI contributions to PO literature and identifies areas of opportunity for future research.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Diversification of investments is a well-established practice used for reducing the total risk of investing for ages in the early history of portfolio theory [1]. A simple diversification strategy that spreads investment into different securities from various sectors, companies, businesses, locations and governments is commonly used. This strategy when applied alone may overlook the big picture since the attention is given on the individual securities rather than the relationship among the securities. Markowitz [2] proposed the mean-variance (M-V) model that brings a quantitative approach to portfolio management by using variance as a measure of economic risk for a desired efficient diversification of securities. Thus, in addition to the characteristics of individual securities, the relationships among all securities can also be considered. Although the use of variance as a risk measure [2,3] has been a touchstone in the history of portfolio theory, alternative risk measures such as Variance with skewness (VwS) [4], Value-at-Risk (VaR) [5], Conditional Value-at-Risk (CVaR) [6], Mean-Absolute Deviation (MAD) [7] and Minimax (MM) [8] portfolio optimization models have been proposed in the literature.

Limitations faced by real-life investors weaken the direct applicability of basic PO models, having a lack of specific constraints such as boundary constraints (BC) [9], cardinality constraints (CC) [10], transaction costs (TC) [11] and transaction lots (TL) [7]. Unconstrained portfolio optimization, a typical convex quadratic programming problem, can be efficiently solved by exact approaches such as linear and quadratic programming. However, as proven by Bienstock [10], adding practical restrictions such as cardinality constraints to the model, the problem is converted to mixed-integer quadratic programming which is dragged into NPcomplete class of problems which limits the computational efficiency of exact solution approaches while the problem size increases. Therefore, researchers paid a particular attention on developing approximation methods such as heuristic/metaheuristic algorithms. Evolutionary Algorithms (EA) and Swarm Intelligence (SI) methodologies are two of the most preferred solution approaches for portfolio optimization. Metaxiotis and Liagkouras [12] presented a literature review of multi-objective EA while Kalayci et al. [13] presented a recent review of genetic algorithms for portfolio optimization. Unlike EA utilizing principles of natural selection, SI methodologies are inspired by the behaviors and self-organizing interaction among agents, such as foraging of ant and bee colonies, bird flocking or fish schooling. Some of the SI algorithms adopted for solving PO variants are listed as follows: particle swarm optimization (PSO) [14], ant colony optimization (ACO) [15], bacterial foraging optimization (BFO) [16], artificial bee colony (ABC) [17], cat swarm optimization (CSO) [18], firefly al-

div.head: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
div.p: model based on semi-variance (S-V) [2] which is more preferable for stock returns having an asymmetric distribution. In order to successfully capture the characteristics of the return distribution, another approach is to include skewness into the M-V model [15]. While positive skewness in portfolio returns may lead some reduction in downside risk which is favorable to investors, the coefficient of skewness is affected by returns greater or less than the mean return achieving portfolios with similar skewness but quite different downside behavior.

The M-V model consists of a quadratic objective function and linear constraints. While Markowitz [2] is said to be the father of modern portfolio theory, the M-V model has been criticized because of its structure and therefore, alternative risk measures such as VaR, CVaR, MAD and MM have been proposed in the literature. In order to overcome arising computational difficulties due to the quadratic structure of M-V model, Konno and Yamazaki [7] proposed MAD as an alternative risk measure that employ the mean of the absolute deviations of the portfolio return in all periods as the risk measure. The portfolio return is devised from the corresponding historical returns of the stocks. The risk in this model is measured by absolute deviation of the assets rate of return. Therefore, calculating the covariance matrix is unnecessary with the model having less computational cost and is very easy to update the model when new data are added. Furthermore, its risk function can be transformed into parametric linear programming, and thus portfolio optimization implementation is simplified. However, Simaan [23] reports that, although estimation error is more severe in small samples and for investors with high risk tolerance in both M-V and MAD models, M-V model provides lower estimation risk in small samples and for investors with a low risk tolerance.

Another risk measure is MM, proposed by Young [8]; it is based on game theory, uses minimum return rather than variance as a measure of risk to avoid the logical problems of a quadratic utility function implied by M-V portfolio selection rules. In MM model, portfolio risk is measured by the minimum portfolio return over all periods. Thus, in contrast to M-V and MAD models, in MM model, the risk measure is asymmetric which is claimed to be more appropriate for skewed return distributions [8].

CVaR [6], also known as Mean Excess Loss, Mean Shortfall, or Tail VaR, is proposed to approximate the joint density function by a number of scenarios to obtain a linear model. VaR [5] describing the quantile of the projected distribution of gains and losses over the target horizon measures the worst loss (lowest return) a portfolio can potentially suffer [24]. However, VaR has undesirable mathematical characteristics such as a lack of subadditivity and convexity [6]. CVaR aiming to reduce the risk of high losses based on VaR representing an asymmetric risk measure that can be also used in return and risk analyses.

div.head: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D
Classification of Portfolio Optimization Models
div.p: If the decision-making process and the future events in portfolio optimization are restricted to a one-time period, a single-period portfolio optimization (SPPO) model is under study. Although Markowitz [2,3] also considers multi-period models as a course of its nature where, if desired, the portfolio may be readjusted several times during the planning horizon, studying a sequence of decisions where transactions take place at discrete time points instead of once is analyzed in multi-period portfolio optimization (MPPO) model [25].

div.head: Additional constraints for realistic portfolio management
div.p: Limitations faced by real-life investors weaken the direct applicability of basic PO models, having a lack of specific constraints, where compulsory criteria are required, or easier implementation is desired.

Although unconstrained (UC) model, namely, suggests having no constraints in the model, the following limitations are present in the default unconstrained setting: the investment of all funds is ensured, and short sales are not allowed. The investment of all funds is verified by exactly restricting the sum of security proportions to one and short sales are excluded by utilizing non-negativity constraints [2]. In addition to default unconstrained settings, additional constraints such as boundary constraints (BC) [9], cardinality constraints (CC) [10], transaction costs (TC) [11] and transaction lots (TL) [7] are needed for a more realistic portfolio management.

div.head: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
div.p: 7 Small proportions held in the portfolio have typically little impact on the performance and have weak liquidity and can be usually costly in terms of brokerage fees or monitoring costs. Therefore, in practice, a lower limit preventing the holding of a position if one does not invest in more than the minimal allowable position, called as min-buy or minimum transaction level, may be desired/enforced when clients buy, sell or revise stocks. An upper limit may also be used for flexibility. Therefore, boundary constraints (BC) are added as a constraint in mathematical formulations.

It is not possible for an investor/fund manager to purchase all the securities in the index according to their weights. Therefore, a common practice is to purchase just a subset of the entire set of securities for easier management of the portfolio. Therefore under such circumstances, on top of enforcing boundaries, cardinality constraints [10] are also needed to define an upper limit on the number of securities to be held in a portfolio.

In any financial market, investors are obliged to pay transaction costs (TC) [11] for the purchases, sales, revisions of securities caused by commissions, liquidity costs, taxes or fund loans. Transaction costs may be fixed or variable related to the amount traded [29], proportional to the total price of the stocks. In the absence of transactions costs, the models are far from being realistic since presence of transaction costs may not only affect the anticipated outcome, but also significantly affect investors' behaviors. Therefore, the money consumed by transaction costs must be considered in the mathematical formulations.

In real world, the investment proportion of portfolio for each security cannot be represented by real numbers since each security has its minimum transaction lot [7] . Therefore, it is necessary to consider minimum/maximum transaction units by rounding the numbers to multiples of this minimal/maximal unit [30].
Table 2 presents a summary of constraints proposed to deal with real life challenges in portfolio management.

div.head: Table 2. Constraints for realistic portfolio management
div.p: Unconstrained (UC) [2]:
-Ensure the investment of all funds -Do not allow short sales Boundary Constraints (BC), also known as buy-in threshold [9]:
-Limit the minimum and maximum investment Cardinality Constraints (CC) [10]:
-Restrict the number of assets in the portfolio Transaction Costs (TC) [11]:
-Deduct transaction costs from the outcome Transaction Lots (TL) [7]:

-Round the minimum and maximum number of transaction lots to nearest integer value SI literature review reveals the distribution of constraints considered in portfolio optimization models as given in Figure 3. The dominancy of BC and CC over other constraints is observed.

div.head: A quick peek into methodologies adopted for portfolio optimization
div.p: A portfolio optimization literature review reveals the exact and approximation attempts on solving different variants of the problem. Unconstrained portfolio optimization, a typical convex quadratic programming problem, can be efficiently solved by exact approaches such as linear and quadratic programming. However, as proven by Bienstock [10], adding practical restrictions such as cardinality constraints to the model, the problem is converted to mixedinteger quadratic programming which is dragged into NP-complete class of problems. Therefore, researchers have been pushing the development of approximation techniques such as machine learning algorithms and metaheuristics. Machine learning algorithms evolving from computational learning theory in artificial intelligence such as artificial neural networks [31],
artificial immune system [32] and k-means clustering [33] are less opted for than metaheuristic algorithms which either being single solution based or population based in the literature.

Single solution based metaheuristic algorithms such as simulated annealing [34], tabu search [34,35], greedy randomized adaptive search [36] the first adaptation [34] was made in the beginning of this century. Although Chang et al. [34] reported that no algorithm outperformed others in solving a PO problem variant when GA, TS and SA are compared, Ehrgott et al. [38] claimed that GA, a well-known branch of EA, achieved best results and ran most stable. Due to the numerous attempts on solving portfolio optimization problem variants by EA, a considerable amount of articles has been published to review EA applications for PO. Metaxiotis and Liagkouras [12] provides a comprehensive literature review on the implementations of multi-objective evolutionary algorithms for portfolio management research field while Kalayci et al. [13] presents a review on mean-variance portfolio optimization dedicated to GA applications. Interested reader is referred to [39][40][41][42] for a more detailed evaluation of EA in portfolio optimization domain. Unlike EA, SI algo-

div.head: Swarm intelligence algorithms
div.p: Swarm intelligence (SI) concept firstly mentioned by Beni and Wang [43] is a sub-discipline of computational intelligence that aims to solve problems by modeling populations of agents that can self-organize and interact with each other. Agents can exchange information to share their experiences. The combination of movements and interactions of these simple agents leads to the performance of population.

In In general, the most significant characteristics of metaheuristics are exploitation (intensification) and exploration (diversification). Exploitation intends to keep on pushing the information from the current best solutions by searching around the neighborhood of the incumbent solutions and selecting the best candidates while exploration ensures that the algorithm can further explore the search space as diversely as possible, often utilizing various randomization strategies which are essential for the algorithm to jump out of any local optima.

Swarm based algorithms adopted for PO problem in the literature are listed in Table 3 and summarized by classifying them according to inspiration phenomenon, original application area, exploitation and exploration mechanisms.

div.head: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
Particle swarm optimization
div.p: The particle swarm optimization (PSO) technique, firstly introduced by Kennedy and Eberhart [14], is a metaheuristic algorithm categorized in swarm intelligence methodologies that mimics the coordinated behavior of birds and fish moving in flocks that transfer information across the group in order to aid decision-making process in a synchronized manner.

When searching for food, each member, namely a particle, adjusts its position and speed by evaluating both its own experience and the experience of other particles in the flock. In the PSO technique, a particle moves from a position to another position in the multidimensional solution space seeking to converge an optimal solution. A position on the solution space corresponds to a solution of problem under study. In general, the behavior of each particle is adjusted by performing a compromise between the group memory and the individual memory.
The basic steps of PSO are given in Table 5.
Table 5. Main steps of PSO algorithm

Step Explanation 1 Create an initial population. Most commonly applied swarm-based approach for the portfolio optimization problem in the literature is PSO. This approach was first applied by Chen et al. [98] to the portfolio optimization problem using M-V model with BC and TC evaluating and confirming its performance on the stock market of China. Cura [68] compared the PSO algorithm with the Genetic Algorithm (GA), Simulated Annealing (SA) and Tabu Search (TS) algorithms and reported that no technique could outperform others. Niu et al. [65] proposed a symbiotic multi-swarm PSO (SMPSO) algorithm inspired by the phenomenon of symbiosis in natural ecosystems. They used a multiple swarms scheme in which the whole population is divided into several subswarms where any sub-swarm is enhanced by utilizing the experiences of other sub-swarms.
Chen and Zhang [103] designed an improved PSO by introducing an enhanced velocity calculation procedure and a penalty function. Zhu et al. [53] provided a comparison between PSO

div.head: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
div.p: and ACO reporting that ACO slightly outperformed PSO on portfolios with small-sized and large-sized while PSO slightly outperformed ACO on medium-sized portfolios. Zhu et al.

[54] compared the PSO technique with GA and recommended the use of hybrid techniques to improve PSO performance. Sun et al. [27] has developed a discrete particle swarm optimization (DPSO) algorithm and compared it with a continuous PSO, GA and some conventional optimization solvers such as LOQO and CPLEX. The DPSO algorithm outperformed other methods in terms of convergence rates and computation times. Golmakani and Fazel [70] also compared the proposed PSO algorithm with the GA and obtained better results. Deng et al.
[72] developed a PSO technique outperforming other PSO techniques in the literature.
Corazza et al. [107] added a penalty function to improve the performance of the algorithm.
Non-dominated Sorting Multi Objective PSO (NS-MOPSO) algorithm was developed by Mishra et al. [77] and has been applied to portfolio optimization problem with BC and CC.

The performance of the proposed approach is compared with four single objective evolutionary algorithms, such as GA, TS, SA, PSO and a set of competitive multi-objective evolutionary algorithms having non-dominated sorting based or decomposition-based frameworks. The computational results exhibited the improved performance of the proposed NS-MOPSO algorithm. Yin et al. [79] proposed heterogeneous multiple population PSO (HMPPSO) and applied M-V model with BC and CC. Comparisons with other classic PSO variants show that HMPPSO is more effective and robust, especially for problems with high dimensions.

In PSO, a particle moves towards a direction based on its personal position and the position of the best particle of the population to determine its new location. Most of the researchers used the original formulation to update the velocity, which is defined as follows:
div.formula: ‫ݒ‬ ௪ ሬሬሬሬሬሬሬሬሬԦ = ‫ݒݓ‬ ௗ ሬሬሬሬሬሬሬԦ + ܿ ଵ × ܷ ሬ ሬԦ ⊗ ൫‫‬ ሬሬሬሬԦ -‫ݔ‬ ሬሬሬԦ൯ + ܿ ଶ × ܷ ሬ ሬԦ ⊗ ‫(‬ ሬሬሬሬԦ -‫ݔ‬ ሬሬሬԦ) (4.1)
div.p: where ‫ݓ‬ is called inertia weight that controls the balance between global and local experience, ‫ݒ‬ ௗ ሬሬሬሬሬሬሬԦ represents previous velocity vector of the particles, ܷ ሬ ሬԦ represents a vector of uniformly distributed random numbers in ሾ0,1ሿ which is generated for each particle in each itera- Xu and Chen [45] adopted a velocity limiting scheme, defining lower and upper limits to particle velocity, thus the search process is kept under control. Liu and Wang [119] adopted an elite archiving scheme to store non-dominated solutions. Wang et al. [50], in order to maintain the diversity of swarm, dissimilarities among particles are increased by using a crossover operator inherited from differential evolution algorithm, and thus, a greater computational efficiency is achieved since calculation of velocity is much expensive. Yaakob and Watada [69],

in addition to defined lower and upper limits for particle velocity, added a mutation operator, inherited from GA, to PSO algorithm that increases the diversity of the population by introducing new genetic material into an existing individual with a mutation probability. Mozafari et al. [71] integrates an SA procedure, as a local search mechanism around this global best solution, into PSO algorithm in order to escape from local optima and to improve the precision of convergence. Deng et al. [72] proposed an enhanced increased exploration in the initial search steps and improved convergence speed in the final search steps. Corazza et al.
[107] proposed a non-differentiable exact penalty formulation for constraint handling. ܿ ଵ = ܿ ଶ = 1.367 ‫ݓ‬ = 0.9 ‫ݓ‬ = 0.9, ‫ݓ‬ = 0.4 multiple swarms scheme structure 2010 Yaakob and Watada [69] 20

div.p: added a mutation operator to PSO algorithm that adds diversity to the genetic characteristics of the population.

Mozafari et al. [71] 50 : social learning factor; : cognitive learning factor; : inertial weight factor; : an upper limit for particle velocity; : a lower limit for particle velocity; : initial value for inertial weight factor; : minimum value that inertial weight factor can take; : initial value for social or cognitive learning factor; : minimum value that social or cognitive learning factor can take.

div.head: Artificial bee colony
div.p: Artificial Bee Colony (ABC) algorithm was proposed by Karaboga [17] based on intelligent behaviors of bee swarms. Bees are social insects living in colonies in the nature. There are three types of bees in the colony: employed bees, onlooker bees and scout bees. Employed bees exploit and share the information of nectar amount with the colony via a dance called "waggle dance". An onlooker bee in the hive watches this waggle dance and adjusts its direction according to the quality of nectar deciding on which nutrient source to target. When all known sources of nutrients have been adequately exploited, scout bees search for new sources of nutrients. Scout bees job is to randomly discover new food sources. The position of a food source corresponds to a solution of the problem while the nectar amount represents the quality of that solution. The basic steps of ABC algorithm are given in Table 7. GA, TS, SA [34] and PSO [68] and reported that ABC performed well for solving the PO problem and obtained better solutions than other heuristic algorithms. Chen et al. [87] reported that the generation of scout bees from a standard initial population provides strong diversity but may deprive of solution quality. Therefore, they proposed an improved ABC algorithm that provides a balance between exploration and exploitation. Compared results showed that, improved ABC algorithm outperformed VNS, SA, TS and standard ABC in terms of diversity, convergence, and effectiveness. Bacanin et al. [64] applied ABC to constrained PO problem with an efficient constraint handling method. They compared ABC algorithm with GA and FA and pointed out ABC algorithm's potential on effectively solving PO problems.

div.head: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
div.p: Suthiwong and Sodanil [90], in order to improve the exploitation capability of employed bee phase, proposed an ABC algorithm inspired by PSO that takes advantage of the information of the global best solution to guide the search. Ge [88] proposed another promising ABC algorithm that outperforms standard ABC. Kumar and Mishra [106] proposed a powerful covariance guided ABC algorithm for portfolio optimization with cardinality constraints and investment limit constraints and tested on benchmark data sets from OR-library confirming its capability of handling real life portfolio management tasks. Kalayci et al. [91] proposed a novel methodology based on ABC algorithm, confirming its superior performance on bench-

div.head: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D
div.p: mark data sets from OR-Library, with feasibility enforcement and infeasibility toleration procedures that handles BC and CC efficiently.

Table 8 presents some enhanced ABC algorithms adopted for solving PO variants with number of food sources and employed parameter configuration as well as unique contribution of the related study. Number of food sources was either set to a predetermined value [88,91,109] or adjusted according to problem dimension [85,87,91,106] in the literature. Number of employed, onlooker and scout bees are based on number of food sources while limit, a parameter to decide on the exact release time of scout bees to explore new food sources, was either fixed [85,87,88] or adjusted according to problem dimension [91,106].
Table 8. Enhanced ABC algorithms adopted for solving PO variants limit: a parameter to decide on the exact release time of scout bees to explore new food sources.

div.head: Other swarm-based algorithms
div.p: Researchers are inspired not only from birds, fishes and bees but also ants, behaviors of bacteria, bats and fireflies. In this section, other swarm intelligence methodologies such as ant colony optimization (ACO), bacterial foraging optimization (BFO), firefly algorithm (FA) and bat algorithm (BA) adopted for solving PO variants are discussed.
Ant system inspired by the hunting strategies of ants was first mentioned by Dorigo et al. [15]. Ants, during search for food in nature, unlike fish, birds and bees utilize an indirect

div.head: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D
div.p: ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT 20 communication strategy, called as stigmergy. Chemical substances, pheromones, are left in the path of travelling ants. Ants, capable of sensing the pheromone, tend to be attracted by pheromones and therefore follow the paths with denser pheromone levels. As ants follow the same path, that path becomes more attractive since the concentration of pheromone is increased. If there is any obstacles in the path, a random movement is made in the beginning, but sooner or later ant will find the shortest path utilizing the pheromone information [122].

Ant colony optimization (ACO) was firstly proposed to solve travelling salesman problem [123]. Therefore, ACO solution mechanism is basically suitable for discrete problems. For the implementation of ACO to PO, ACO must be adopted to work in continuous domain due to the structure of PO problem.

In continuous domain, representing the pheromones in the form of a matrix is hardly possible due to the fact that continuous data can occupy any value over a continuous range, an infinite number of possibilities exist, and on the contrary computer memory is limited. Socha and Dorigo [124] proposed a continuous version of ACO, called as ACO ℝ . Khalidji et al. [113] proposed a bi-objective continuous ant colony optimization called dynamically weighted ACO ℝ (DW-ACO ℝ ) and compared with non-dominated sorting genetic algorithm (NSGA-II)
and reported that the solutions obtained by DW-ACO ℝ were closer to the Pareto front. Deng

and Lin [97] compared ACO ℝ with PSO and concluded that ACO ℝ is more robust and effective, especially for low-risk investments. Zhu et al. [53] presented a study that compares the performance of ACO ℝ and PSO reporting that in small-scale and large-scale portfolio cases, ACO ℝ ended up with slightly better results than PSO, but in the case of medium-scale portfolio, the PSO performed slightly better than the ACO ℝ .

Bacteria foraging optimization (BFO) algorithm was inspired by the organized activities in bacterial foraging and the survival of bacteria in different environments [16]. A BFO algorithm consists of several bacteria, which represent solutions in the optimization problem and consists of three processes: chemotaxis, reproduction, and elimination-dispersal. Kao and Cheng [92] proposed a BFO algorithm and compared with GA, TS, SA [34] and PSO [68] reporting that BFO algorithm was a better choice in finding the efficient frontier. Tan et al.

[59] proposed a modified BFO that utilize a linearly decreasing mechanism into the whole chemotactic movement to keep a right balance of the global search and local search. Experimental results confirmed the superiority of modifications made to BFO in terms of obtaining high quality solutions and robustness. To further improve the performance of BFO, Niu et al.
[58] proposed a modified BFO algorithm in which BFO has a linear deceasing chemotaxis (BFO-LDC) that outperforms GA, PSO and the standard BFO.

div.head: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D
div.p: Firefly algorithm (FA) inspired by the flashing patterns and behaviors of fireflies [19] was also adopted to solve PO. Bacanin and Tuba [95] presented a modified FA utilizing ‫ݐ݈݅݉݅‬ parameter of ABC that controls and directs the exploration process to avoid unnecessary exploration and compared against GA, TS, SA [34] and PSO [68] reporting that FA was the best performer. Tuba and Bacanin [96] enhanced standard FA approach by introducing a more intensive exploitation mechanism in later iterations and compared against GA, TS, SA [34] and population based incremental learning differential evolution (PBILDE) [125] reporting that FA outperformed the original FA for all performance indicators and was better than other algorithms in most cases.

div.head: Hybrid applications
div.p: The hybridization technique that combines two heuristic methods, is applied to improve the performance of algorithms proposed by many researchers. Table 9 presents some hybrid implementations of SI algorithms adopted for solving PO variants. Strumberger et al. [61] proposed a promising hybrid algorithm that combines BA and ABC.

div.head: Multi-objective algorithms
div.p: SI algorithms can be classified in two categories according to the evaluation of objectives:

single-objective type and multi-objective type. Figure 5 demonstrates the distribution of SI Algorithms according to objective handling methodology where single-objective types are highly dominant over multi-objective types.

div.head: Problem specific application contexts
div.p: This section presents a review on the platforms for coding SI algorithms, how constraints are handled, used datasets and performance measures in SI literature for portfolio optimization.

div.head: Implementation Platforms
div.p: Table 10 presents a summary on SI Algorithms adopted for PO, implementation platforms as well as data sets employed to validate the performance of the algorithms. Figure 6 demonstrates the distribution of implementation platforms for SI algorithms. C++ is a generalpurpose programming language providing facilities for low-level memory manipulation. C#, developed by Microsoft within its .NET initiative, is one of the programming languages designed for the common language infrastructure. Java is a programming language intended to let application developers to run compiled Java code on all platforms regardless of computer architecture. MATLAB is a specialized language for scientific and technical computing primarily intended for numerical computing that allows matrix manipulations with its built-in structure. Although 44% of the examined studies do not refer to any implementation platform, 27% of the studies preferred MATLAB language while 14% C++, 12% C# and 3% preferred to code in JAVA programming languages. [
Bacanin et al. [64] Kalayci et al.

div.head: Constraint handling
div.p: Portfolio optimization models encompass real-life constraints such as BC, CC, TC and TL in addition to unconstrained setting for practical portfolio management. In order to achieve feasible solutions in the literature, repair procedures [52, 54, 55, 63, 72, 74, 77, 79, 82, 83, 86, 87, 91-93, 97, 106, 113, 115], penalty functions [57, 58, 60, 68, 70, 71, 73, 94-96, 98, 99, 101-104, 107, 108, 110] or Deb et al. [126]'s strategy [64,84,89,91]

div.head: Datasets
div.p: In the literature, researchers used various data sets to report the experimental results of the algorithms developed. Some researchers reported experimental results employed on case studies from active stock markets from China [28, 47, 49, 53-55, 58, 63, 65, 88, 102, 105, 109, 116, 117], USA [27,82,94,99,103,104,107,110,112], Iran [26,52,60,75,113], Italy [74],

Pakistan [32], Saudi Arabia [114], Taiwan [48,62], Thailand [90], India [77], Turkey [91] while some others used benchmark datasets, accessible on the OR-Library [127], to compare algorithms' performance. The data on OR-Library corresponds to the weekly prices between Firstly, Chang et al. [34], in order to measure the distance of heuristic efficient frontier to continuous unconstrained efficient frontier, utilized linear interpolation methodology and portfolio standard deviation on both looking into vertical and horizontal directions that quantifies the percentage deviation (distance) in the case of a linearly interpolated efficient frontier.

Thus, mean percentage error measure and median percentage error measures have been introduced and later utilized in [72,76,81,85,87,92,95,96] for benchmarking purposes. Then, Fernández and Gómez [31] and Cura [68] introduced two additional error measures: variance of return error for variances and mean return error for mean returns which was later utilized in 30 [81]. Cura [68] also defined a mean Euclidian distance error formulation to measure the quality of heuristic solutions which was later utilized in [71, 73, 77-81, 84, 86, 89, 92]. The error measures mentioned above meet at a common ground such that they can be all used in single objective formulations for efficiently calculating the heuristic distance from unconstrained efficient frontier. However, such formulations bring along a major disadvantage of not being able to measure diversity of solutions. Unlike in single-objective optimization, there are two goals in a multi-objective optimization: convergence to the Pareto optimal set and maintenance of diversity in solutions. Therefore, for testing the efficiency of multi-objective problems, Deb et al. [126] introduced a diversity metric measuring the spread of points, i.e. how evenly distributed, which was successfully adapted to measure portfolio performance in [77,83,106].

div.head: Discussion
div.p: Despite all the criticism on the mean-variance model of Markowitz [2], the majority of the studies examined are based on his formulation. Therefore, the most commonly used risk measure in portfolio optimization is the variance. Although multi-period portfolio optimization models make more sense in practical applicability, it received less attention compared to single-period portfolio optimization models. Mathematical models with realistic constraints on the other hand, are gaining popularity. Considering this trend, further constraints in the near future may be introduced to the literature that would contribute to realistic portfolio management. Real-life constraints faced by investors/managers in portfolio management give birth an adequately complex problem: constrained portfolio optimization. In fact, the problem is known to be NP-hard, which compels the development of efficient algorithms. In the path of designing and implementing efficient algorithms, benchmarking data sets enable the comparison of various algorithms in terms of solution quality and time. Although solution quality seems to be more critical, in order to catch up with the rapidly evolving financial aspects in the world, faster algorithms that quickly respond to various inputs are becoming increasingly required. Benchmarking datasets and performance measures are crucial for enabling the comparison of developed algorithms' performance. Therefore, testing and validating the performance of the algorithms on the benchmarking data sets with performance measures provided in the literature as well as expanding the benchmarking datasets available in the OR-Library [127] would serve well to the portfolio optimization domain.

In the class of approximation algorithms, SI algorithms have received great attention in the PO literature. PSO algorithm [14] is by far the most adopted SI approach for solving the PO problem. There may be two major reasons; first, the PSO algorithm is relatively older than others, second, PSO algorithm is a good fit to the continuous PO problem solving since the framework of the original PSO is in the continuous optimization domain, thus, transformation is not necessary. Although there are so many applications of ACO algorithm in the NP-hard class of optimization problems, there are a few implementations on portfolio optimization.

Primary reason may be the necessity of transforming into continuous domain since the ACO methodology was originally designed [123] to work on discrete problems. Nevertheless, continuous variants of the ACO methodology [124,128] In fact, some [91,106] achieved superior performance among competing algorithms in PO domain. Therefore, in this field, the ABC algorithm may attract more attention in the near future. BFO [16] is observed as another promising algorithm considering its continuous nature and several successful applications in continuous optimization domain as well as in solving PO [58,92,93]. IWO [20], FA [19], FWA [22], CSO [18] and BA [21] are recent candidates in continuous optimization domain as well as in solving PO [60,61,95,108].

Exploitation and exploration mechanisms play critical roles in the performance of metaheuristics. Pushing the information on better solutions is carried through exploitation while further exploring the search space as diversely as possible is achieved by exploration mechanisms. If the exploitation mechanism does not adequately push through, the algorithm may fail to reach global optima. On the other hand, if exploration mechanism does not achieve adequate diversification, the algorithm may stick into some local optima. A proper compromise between these conflicting mechanisms is essential for an algorithm to be able to both jump out of a local optimum and achieve a precise convergence. Therefore, in order to achieve such a performance, sometimes a hybridization approach that combines positive characteristics of multiple algorithms would improve algorithms' performance. In order to avoid premature convergence, some enhancement attempts were made by combining the intensification capability of BA and FA with exploration mechanism of ABC algorithm [61,89], by limiting the particle movement speed of PSO utilizing HNN [73]. Since matheuristics, an interoperation of metaheuristics and mathematical programming techniques, are gaining popularity [132] in optimization literature, perhaps, even more enhanced efficiency can be achieved by combining exact and SI algorithms to tackle portfolio optimization problems in the near future.
Single and multi-objective methodologies differ in the way of treating objective functions.

Single objective methodologies often make use of a weighted sum approach to obtain a single objective to be optimized while multi-objective methodologies simultaneously manage multiple objectives. Although multi-objective EA literature on PO is well-built [12] and highly competitive results are achieved by multi-objective PSO algorithms [49,55,77,82,83,105] and multi-objective BFO [93] algorithm against multi-objective EA, the performance of multi-objective SI algorithms is not adequately explored.

Another critical factor for algorithm performance is the constraint handling methodology that ensures the feasibility of generated solutions. Compared to EA [133], constraint handling aspect is rather less explored in SI algorithms where, often, a repair procedure or penalty functions are utilized. The computational complexity of the PO problem along with the practical importance of portfolio management triggers the researchers' motivation to design efficient algorithms racing against time. Therefore, computational efficiency related improvements on SI methodologies contributing to this domain is always welcome.

div.head: Conclusion and future research directions
div.p: The identified gaps in literature to clarify the future research opportunities for interested authors are as follows:

-While SI algorithms play an important role in the literature of portfolio optimization, there is a need for a more comprehensive and detailed literature review including exact solution techniques and other heuristic algorithms to gain a better understanding of the whole literature on PO.
-An analysis of local search techniques employed in continuous optimization domain would be useful to PO problem solving.

-Enhanced variants of single and multi-objective variants of SI algorithms based on continuous ACO, BFO, IWO, ABC, FA, FWA for solving single and multi-period PO problems would contribute to realistic portfolio management given that algorithms' performances are validated.
-Expanding the benchmarking datasets available in the OR-Library would serve well to the portfolio optimization domain.
-Combining exact solution techniques or successful local search methodologies with SI algorithms for PO problem solving would contribute to PO domain as promised in continuous optimization domain.

-Exploitation and exploration mechanisms as well as constraint handling methodologies of SI algorithms that may lead algorithmic enhancements in PO domain require a careful attention and should be further investigated.

figure.head: Figure 5 .
figure.figDesc: Figure 5. Classification of SI Algorithms according to objective handling methodology Researchers develop multi-objective algorithms to solve PO because of its bi-objective (minimizing risk and maximizing return) structure. Multi-objective PSO (MOPSO) is the most preferred multi-objective swarm based algorithm for PO in the literature. Mishra et al. [49]compared the following four multi-objective algorithms; parallel single front GA, strength Pareto evolutionary algorithm (SPEA2), non-dominated sorting genetic algorithm (NSGA-II) against MOPSO. Experimental results showed that the MOPSO significantly outperformed its counterparts in all experiments. Wang and Watada[111] built multi-objective using VaR as the risk measure and developed MOPSO algorithms for effectively solving the multi-objective portfolio selection problem. They noted that the resulting portfolio selection models are very helpful for investors in decision making and MOPSO algorithms are effective in finding the

figure.head: 29 Figure 8 .
figure.figDesc: Figure 8. Distribution of utilized datasets for performance evaluation5.3. Performance measuresLiterature analysis shows that various researchers use many different performance measures to validate the performance of their algorithm on the data sets (OR-Library[127]) provided by Chang et al.[34]. These data sets provide weekly price data from March 1992 to September 1997 including mean return values, standard deviation of return values, correlation coefficients and finally an efficient frontier obtained by calculating 2000 distinct points on the continuous exact UC efficient frontier. While the 2000 distinct points represent the UC efficient frontier, the outcome of a heuristic algorithm creates a heuristic efficient frontier, usually consisting of 50 distinct points. Therefore, it is required to have a formulation for the error measure calculation.

figure.head: Figure 9
figure.figDesc: demonstrates the distribution of performance measures utilized in SI literature for portfolio optimization. It is observed that only 4 algorithms out of 76 in total employed diversity metric proposed by Deb et al.[126] while others employed the performance measures introduced by Chang et al.[34], Fernández and Gómez[31] and Cura[68].

figure.head: Figure 9 .
figure.figDesc: Figure 9. Distribution of performance measures utilized in SI literature for portfolio optimization In addition to the solution quality, computation time is another indicator of performance that points out to how fast and efficient an algorithm is. However, since the hardware configuration of various algorithms competing each other differ, it is hard to tell the winner in such a competition. Therefore, a reliable hardware benchmark evaluation study is required prior to evaluation of algorithm performance for a fair comparison.

have been recently introduced to the literature with promising performance on continuous optimization. Likewise, ABC algorithm[17] has less applications in PO domain compared to PSO even though the ABC algorithm has a direct fit on PO problem structure. However, the ABC algorithm being a decade younger than PSO had received an increasing attention in the past few years[64, 67, 84-91, 106,

the related works of SI algorithms adopted for PO problem. In this frame, the search was conducted on major scientific databases such as Web of Science, Science Direct, Springer Link, Scopus and Google Scholar. Related publications were published in various journals and conference proceedings. In total, 76 published papers between 2006 and March 2017 are reviewed, categorized, and analyzed to enlighten the path of the future opportunities of research. Classifications were made according to problem model, real-life constraints, solution approach and application contexts.

figure.figDesc: Yaakob and Watada [69] proposed a hybrid model called Velocity Control Hybrid PSO (VC-HPSO) to take particle velocity under control. Table6presents some enhanced PSO algorithms adopted for solving PO variants with number of particles and employed parameter configuration as well as unique contribution of the related study. Number of particles have a direct influence on computation time of each iteration. Therefore, most researchers preferred to use less number of particles[45,50,65,69,[119][120][121]. However, some others tried to use a greater number of particles[72,79,107] in their implementations. Although algorithm parameters of PSO are fixed to predefined values[45,50,65] by some researchers, some others employed adaptive parameter values[69,71,72,107], gradually decreasing throughout iterations, in order to achieve a precise convergence at final iterations.

A C C E P T E D

note.p: tion, ⊗ is component-wise multiplication, ‫ݔ‬ ሬሬሬԦ represents the current position of the particles, ‫‬ and ‫‬ represents personal and global best positions respectively. Although many researchers used Eq. (3.1), some researchers have resorted to different methods to update velocity. Xu and Chen [45] proposed a heuristic algorithm called Velocity Limited PSO (VLPSO) and reported that VLPSO algorithm can reach the optimal solution in less iterations, and it has better convergence efficiency and precision than standard PSO. Koshino et al. [46] proposed Constriction Factor Approach (CFA) that adds a new parameter into velocity update equation.

note.p: Hong-mei et al.[109] was first to apply ABC to PO problem and compared with GA. Test results showed that ABC outperformed the GA in terms of convergence speed and solution quality. Chen et al.[85] applied ABC to PO and compared with variable neighborhood search (VNS), SA, and TS algorithms in the literature reporting that ABC outperformed others in terms of diversity, convergence, and effectiveness. Wang et al.[117] proposed a hybrid implementation of GA and PSO to solve PO with MAD model. div.head: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
A survey of swarm intelligence for portfolio optimization: Algorithms and applications HIGHLIGHTS
div.p: • Swarm intelligence applications on portfolio optimization are reviewed.
• Papers published between 2006 and 2017 are reviewed.
• Several classifications related to models and algorithmic components are presented.
• Crucial components of analyzed algorithms are outlined.
• Lines for further research are proposed.
